title: Shen, Zed, and Jhin

replies.body:
Shen, Zed, and Jhin, sitting in a tree. K. I. L. L. I. N. G.

In their history, Jhin is absolutely a protagonist. But Shen doesn't look at Zed with any kind of fondness, only with betrayal. The man he thought was his brother murdered his father, the person that Shen defined himself by.

However, it's true that Shen can't give into his own immediate, visceral anger. Perhaps he even tells himself he doesn't hold that anger against Zed. His job does require him to hold that inner balance to perform it. It's a role that he does partly in honor of his father. 
Still, if Shen told you he isn't angry, would you believe him?

When he has two worlds balanced on the edge of a blade, how long any man keep his hand steady?

I'm not going to talk about where their story might be headed in specifics, but those are the things that are involved in our thinking.

Thanks, oOoilcelceBabyoOo.

On a slightly unrelated but kinda related note I kinda wanna know how Akali and Kennen view Shen now and how they became a part of the Kinkou. In my head I feel like they almost fit better as being folks who joined _after_ Zed dismantled the old order as part of Shen's rebuilding of things, but I dunno.

Oh Jaredan is Shen's ninja order still called the Kinkou?

I'm curious too about Kennen and Akali's  characters as well ever since the events of Shen's father had passed. 

We know that Akali wants Zed dead for some reason while Kennen seems more willing to forgive him - is it possible that Kennen and Akali represent the good and evil within Shen's view of Zed after his father was slain? Whether to forgive Zed or to ultimately kill the one he thought of as a brother?

I really like that shen is seeing some lore love. Him being the second champ I considered a main, he is very dear tome. Also the rework was awesome xD I'm glad their keeping the mystical ninja vibe going and hearing that Jhin bears malice against Shen and Zed and wanted to be the one that killed shen's father, it leaves a lot to think about. This just might get me back into reading lore :3

Being neutral in the face of 'evil' isn't balance though. Balance isn't an absence necessarily, it can be holding equal parts of two opposites and using the proper one. Lack of emotions can kill motivations. If someone is 'balanced' in their emotions, how do they decide what to do if there are no emotional pulls towards one action or another?

Also, what is Shen's job? What does his order balance upon? What's their metric for balance? As it is defined now, it's quite arbitrary.

:O Didn't think a red would reply to this. Thanks for the insight :D

However I also have a couple of questions stemming from this: 

While I do agree that Shen wouldn't look at Zed with any sort of fondness, would he, if the time arised, be required to put aside that feeling of betrayal and "forgive" Zed?

And what would Zed do if Shen would "forgive" him, or if Zed realized he is going down the wrong path? I don't think he'd walk up to Shen with a box of chocolate and flowers, but I feel that Zed would have some way of showing his regret for the things he did.
Yeah. I was thinking about that when I read jhin lore.. Would be very interesting !  Please Rito !
